xwikidoc.title: Think Medicare for All is a good idea Fly to LAX and call an Uber

object.name: Articles.Think Medicare for All is a good idea Fly to LAX and call an Uber.WebHome

property.overview: The author gives an example of meeting an Uber driver at an airport, points out that "officials had a plan for that", and then points out that "officials have a plan for Medicare For All, too". He invites the reader to believe that some sort of "Plans by officials always fail" rule from just the one airport example, and then apply that rule to Medicare For All. In doing so, he uses just one example to "prove" this rule, and the rule is *far* too general.

object.name: Articles.Think Medicare for All is a good idea Fly to LAX and call an Uber.WebHome

property.title: Think Medicare for All is a good idea Fly to LAX and call an Uber

object.name: Articles.Think Medicare for All is a good idea Fly to LAX and call an Uber.WebHome

property.quote: gridlock so severe it takes an hour to drive the final half-mile into the airport.

property.rebuttal: This is likely hyperbole. Did it really take an hour? Exactly? How long does it usually take?

object.name: Articles.Think Medicare for All is a good idea Fly to LAX and call an Uber.WebHome

property.rebuttal: Which officials? Did you talk to them? What did they say? Are you sure it was "stunned" and not just "disappointed" or "surprised?"

object.name: Articles.Think Medicare for All is a good idea Fly to LAX and call an Uber.WebHome

property.quote: they had a plan for that. And it was flawless.

property.rebuttal: Did someone actually claim it was "flawless"? Or even "good" for that matter? This statement about "flawless" does nothing to add to the article, other than to use Sarcasm to convey contempt.

object.name: Articles.Think Medicare for All is a good idea Fly to LAX and call an Uber.WebHome
Articles.Think Medicare for All is a good idea Fly to LAX and call an Uber.WebHome

property.quote: It will relieve congestion when it opens sometime in 2023. Maybe.

property.rebuttal: Is that a long time for this sort of thing? I get the feeling I'm supposed to think it is. Is there reason to believe that it won't complete on time? If it's not completed on time, am I supposed to assume that's the fault of the planners? If so, why?

object.name: Articles.Think Medicare for All is a good idea Fly to LAX and call an Uber.WebHome

property.quote: legions of ride-share cars would somehow fit into one parking area.

property.rebuttal: We're supposed to believe that this parking lot is not big enough? Based on what?

object.name: Articles.Think Medicare for All is a good idea Fly to LAX and call an Uber.WebHome

property.quote: among passengers who have called it “the worst plan ever devised.”

property.rebuttal: actually, just one passenger said that, not multiple.

object.name: Articles.Think Medicare for All is a good idea Fly to LAX and call an Uber.WebHome

property.rebuttal: "scheme" is a loaded word, making it sound evil. "plan" would have been more neutral and fair.

object.name: Articles.Think Medicare for All is a good idea Fly to LAX and call an Uber.WebHome

property.quote: I flew back home into LAX from Austin on the third day of this new plan — and I could smell the panic

property.rebuttal: The subsequent sentences describe people waiting a long time. That's not "panic". And "smell" is hyperbole.

object.name: Articles.Think Medicare for All is a good idea Fly to LAX and call an Uber.WebHome

property.quote: one would imagine somebody saw this disaster coming.

property.rebuttal: "disaster" is a bit of an overstatement.

object.name: Articles.Think Medicare for All is a good idea Fly to LAX and call an Uber.WebHome

property.quote: But airport officials brushed off these concerns. After all, they had a plan. The plan had been run through computer models, road-tested no doubt with some virtual reality software that accounted for every possibility. They were confident, even a bit smug

property.rebuttal: How does he know they were "smug"? There's no evidence given. He is likely just guessing that they were smug.

object.name: Articles.Think Medicare for All is a good idea Fly to LAX and call an Uber.WebHome

property.quote: Well, now, guess what? LAX is enlarging the size of the parking lot, making adjustments to its shuttle schedules

property.rebuttal: That's a good thing, right? And is this evidence that the planners made a mistake at first? Maybe not. Things might have changed since then.

object.name: Articles.Think Medicare for All is a good idea Fly to LAX and call an Uber.WebHome

property.quote: and crossing its collective fingers that this will all work itself out before the arrival of the passenger deluge commonly known as Thanksgiving.

property.rebuttal: How does he know that people are just "crossing fingers" rather than "reasonably expecting"? And "all work itself out" seems to be making things seem worse than they actually are. And things are not "working themselves out", the planners are making specific changes to fix things.

object.name: Articles.Think Medicare for All is a good idea Fly to LAX and call an Uber.WebHome

property.quote: This is not Medicare for All. Except for one thing: The mindset is the same.

property.rebuttal:
The mindset of everyone involved in Medicare For All proposals is the same as the mindset of everyone involved in design of an airport redesign? How does he know all those mindsets?
Also, are we to believe there is some general rule that "all people with plans see those plans fail"? That's how general a rule would need to be to cover both airport redesign and Medicare For All.

object.name: Articles.Think Medicare for All is a good idea Fly to LAX and call an Uber.WebHome

property.quote: People who don’t believe just don’t understand: We. Know. Better.

property.rebuttal: Is the rule here "all people who think 'We know better' who have plans have flawed plans. "?
